Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Description: Core statement: Gene therapy is an innovative transformative treatment that modifies a person's genes to treat or cure a disease, with several agents already approved for use.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: S1. Gene therapy is an innovative approach to treating or curing a disease by introducing a functional gene or inactivating/editing a disease-causing gene.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: Gene therapy is defined as a technique that modifies a personâ€™s genes to treat or cure disease. 1

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: Gene therapies work by introducing a functional gene (transgene) or inactivating/editing a disease-causing gene. 1 2

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description:
Gene therapy works through various approaches, including the following: 3 

  • Gene transfer is the process of introducing a functional copy of a missing or dysfunctional gene, typically through a viral vector.
  •  Gene inactivation (also known as gene silencing) is used when a genetic alteration causes an excess of protein; here, RNA interference (RNAi) can be used to silence or suppress gene expression.
  • Gene editing uses technologies such as zinc finger nucleases, transcriptional activator-like effector nucleases, and clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats, with association protein 9 (CRISPR/CAS9) to edit or replace defective genes.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: S2. Classical gene therapy approaches for inherited monogenic diseases have focused on the delivery of a functional gene (transgene) using an inactivated viral vector.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Gene therapy approaches for inherited monogenic diseases have predominantly focused on the delivery of a functional gene using a viral vector. 4

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description:
For gene transfer, the transferred gene is most frequently a functional copy of a mutated gene. 5 

  • Variant genes can also be added that give rise to a protein with increased activity compared with wild type (e.g., Padua variant of factor IX [FIX]). 6 7

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: In most gene therapy applications, viruses are modified to produce viral vectors by removing all or most of the viral genome, minimizing toxicity and eliminating their ability to cause infectious disease, and replicate. 1 8

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description:
Viral vectors can be divided into predominantly integrating (retrovirus, lentivirus) and predominantly non-integrating (adenovirus and adeno-associated virus [AAV]) vectors. 5 

See Table 1 for an overview of commonly used viral vectors (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: The non-integrating adenoviral and AAV vectors have a DNA genome with a packaging capacity of ~8â€“30 kb and ~5 kb, respectively, and can transduce both dividing and non-dividing cells. 5

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Retroviruses have an RNA genome with a packaging capacity of ~8 kb and possess reverse transcriptase activity, which enables their integration as DNA copies into the host genome; however, retroviruses cannot infect non-dividing cells. 5 9

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Lentiviruses are a subset of retroviruses that share the ability to integrate into the host genome; however, unlike retroviruses, lentiviruses can efficiently transduce both dividing and non-dividing cells. 5 9

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: S3. Functional genes are delivered either directly into the recipient (in vivo gene therapy) using a non-integrating vector or into cells extracted from the recipient (ex vivo gene therapy) using an integrating vector.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description:
In vivo gene therapy directly introduces a predominantly non-integrating vector (e.g., a recombinant (r) AAV vector) into the recipient to deliver a functional gene (transgene) into postmitotic cells. 10 

See Figure 1: Overview of in vivo gene therapy (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Most gene therapy strategies for treating inherited diseases utilize AAV vectors for in vivo gene transfer into postmitotic cell types. 5

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: In vivo gene therapy can be delivered to recipients intravenously or via direct injection into the target tissue. 11 12

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: In ex vivo gene therapy, stem cells are extracted from recipients, transduced with the functional gene using an integrating vector, and then returned to the recipient. Following cell division, the integrated gene is passed on to daughter cells. 10

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Most gene therapy strategies for treating inherited diseases utilize lentiviral vectors for ex vivo gene transfer into hematopoietic and other stem cells. 5

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Both ex vivo and in vitro gene therapy approaches are currently approved for the treatment of inherited monogenic diseases using the addition of a functional gene. 13 14 15 16

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description:
As of May 2021, there are two in vivo rAAV-based and one ex vivo lentiviral-based gene therapy products approved for the treatment of inherited monogenic diseases. 13 14 15 16 17 

See Table 2 for an overview of currently approved products (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: S4. Gene therapy has demonstrated durable benefit to patients from a single administration; however, the long-term effects of gene therapy have yet to be fully characterized.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: The goal of gene therapy for inherited diseases is to achieve durable expression of the therapeutic gene or transgene at a level sufficient to ameliorate or cure disease symptoms with minimal adverse events. 18

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Gene therapy has demonstrated durable clinical benefit (4â€“8 yearsâ€™ follow-up) from a single administration across a number of disease areas. 11 12 19 20

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description:
Sustained clinical benefit has been observed with gene therapy in a number of disease areas. 11 12 19 20 

See Table 3: Overview of durable benefits of gene therapy in clinical studies (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Long-term follow-up of gene therapy is required to fully characterize its safety and efficacy. 21 22 23

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description:
Complications of gene therapy have been observed in clinical trials, including integration events and insertional mutagenesis and immunotoxicity. 18 

See Table 4: Observed complications of gene therapy (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Safety events such as tumorigenesis may not occur for years or decades after vector infusion. 21

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: S5. The first gene therapies were approved by the FDA and EMA in the 2010s.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: The promise of gene therapy was realized in the 2010s with the approval of the first gene therapy products in the US and the EU. 24 25

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description:
Gene therapy products have been approved in the US and EU for inherited monogenic diseases and cancer. 13 14 15 17 24 25 26 

See Table 5: Key regulatory approvals of gene therapy products (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: S6. Rapid advancements in gene therapy are ongoing, with increasing numbers of approved products and more than 1100 active clinical trials ongoing across a range of diseases.

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: Recent approvals of gene therapy products include in vivo rAAV-based and ex vivo lentiviral-based gene therapies for inherited monogenic diseases. 13 14 15 16 17

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description:
In vivo rAAV-based gene therapy products are approved for hereditary retinal dystrophy and spinal muscular atrophy, and an ex vivo lentivirus-based product has conditional approval in the EU for Î²-thalassemia. 13 14 15 16 17 

See Table 5: Key regulatory approvals of gene therapy products (in resources).

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: As of August 2021, there are over 1100 planned or ongoing Phase 1â€“3 interventional clinical trials in gene therapy across disease areas. 27

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description:
The majority of gene therapy clinical trials are in cancer and inherited monogenic diseases. 28 

Gene therapy trials have been conducted in inherited monogenic diseases such as sickle cell disease, hemophilia A and B, spinal muscular atrophy, and Î²-thalassemia, with primary immunodeficiency disorders being the most widely studied. 28

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
SubStatements.Description: Advances in gene therapy are ongoing, with the emergence of optimized viral vectors and early evidence indicating that gene transfer could hold promise for certain diseases. 29 30 31

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Preclinical models have shown that modification of AAV-based vectors can reduce recognition by pre-existing neutralizing antibodies. 30

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Clinical benefits have been reported in trials of the CRISPR/Cas9 drug CTX001 in Î²-thalassemia and sickle cell disease. 31

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Gene therapy may become part of routine care for a range of diseases. 32 33 34

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits

SubStatements.Title: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview (strategic objective: XYZ)
SubStatements.Description: Governments are supporting the development of advanced cell treatments, including gene therapy. 35 36 37

Theme.Name: Pillar 1: Gene therapy overview
Theme.Description: Strategic objective: Provide an overview of gene therapy and its potential benefits
